metadata.title: Nano-ferroelectric for high efficiency overall water splitting under ultrasonic vibration

sections.text:
chemical energy, has emerged as a promising candidate for watersplitting technology. However, the efficiency of the hydrogen production is quite limited. We herein report well-defined 10 nm BaTiO3 nanoparticles (NPs) characterized by a large electromechanical coefficient which induces a high piezoelectric effect. Atomic-resolution high angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and scanning probe microscopy (SPM) suggests that piezoelectric BaTiO3 NPs display a coexistence of multiple phases with low energy barriers and polarization anisotropy which results in a high electromechanical coefficient. Landau free energy modeling also confirms that the greatly reduced polarization anisotropy facilitates polarization rotation. Employing the high piezoelectric properties of BaTiO3 NPs, we demonstrate an overall water-splitting process with the highest hydrogen production efficiency hitherto reported, with a H2 production rate of 655 µmolg -1h-1, which could rival excellent photocatalysis system. This study highlights the potential of
piezoelectric catalysis for overall water splitting.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text:
Hydrogen production from water is one of the most promising ways to address increasing energy demands and associated environmental concerns.[1] Demonstrations of green hydrogen production process by converting various forms of renewable energy, such as solar light, waste heat, and mechanical vibrations into applicable and storable hydrogen energy have aroused increasing interest.[2] Among them, photocatalytic water splitting using oxide semiconductors under sunlight irradiation has been widely reported.[3] However, the practical application of photocatalytic hydrogen production is currently limited due to low quantum efficiency, design complexity, and lack of response in absence of sunlight. Piezocatalysis, the process of utilizing mechanical vibrations energy to directly split water, has recently garnered considerable attention.[4]
Ferroelectric materials, characterized by their strong inversion symmetry breaking with a spontaneous polarization that can be switched by the external electric fields, can generate a piezoelectric effect to induce catalytic behavior.[5] In theory, space charges will be attracted to both crystal surfaces, which are perpendicular to the polarization direction and work by, screening the polarization bound charges.[6] Otherwise, a depolarization field would form and partially cancel the ferroelectricity. The space charges adsorbed on the surface of ferroelectrics could induce a high potential and generate usable electricity.[7] Furthermore, the intensity of polarization could be modulated by oscillation such as ultrasonic vibration and water waves due to the piezoelectric effect, thus enabling space charge adsorption and desorption from surfaces, which could trigger a redox reaction.[8] In other words, through mechanical agitation, the oscillatory polarization state of the ferroelectric induce an imbalanced charge state on the surface, and creates an alternating cascade of a space charge release and attraction and thus generates the redox reaction.[9] At present, modulation of polarization in ferroelectric nanomaterials by ultrasonic vibration is proposed as an effective method to increase the degradation efficiency of waste water.[10] While preliminary experiments have shown that piezoelectric microfibers could directly split pure water to hydrogen and oxygen gases, the H2 evolution is still limited.[4b] The efficiency of H2 production is nowhere near as high as traditional photocatalysis.[11] Therefore, breakthroughs are still necessary to develop nano-ferroelectrics with high piezoelectricity for high efficiency water splitting under ultrasonic vibration.

The atomic-resolution polarization mapping reveals that the high piezoelectricity originates from the coexistence of three ferroelectric phases (T+O+R) in 10 nm BaTiO3 NPs. Landau free energy modeling shows a reduction of polarization anisotropy and thus facilitates polarization rotation. The piezoelectric effect enhancement due to multiphase coexistence with characteristically low energy barriers and polarization dramatically boosts the overall water splitting efficiency. In the piezocatalysis process, H2/O2 production rate are 655 µmolg-1h-1 and 316 µmolg-1h-1 under 60 kHz ultrasonic which rival those reported excellent photocatalyst.[3c,12]

sections.heading: Results and Discussion
sections.text:
The 10 nm BaTiO3 NPs with uniform cubic shapes were obtained by a two-phase (water and n-butyl alcohol) solvothermal method containing oleic acid and oleylamine (Figure 1a and Figure S1).[13] As clearly shown in the highresolution TEM (HRTEM) image (Figure 1b), the lattice fringes of a single particle with an interplanar spacing d (110)=2.82 Å are consistent with a perovskite crystal structure, suggesting a high degree of crystallinity. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis in the 2θ range of 70o-90o also reveals the absence of any peaks other than that of the perovskite phase of BaTiO3 nanocubes (Figure 1c). Owing to the ferroelectric transition of BaTiO3 at 120
oC, high-resolution XRD measurements were repeated in the 2θ range of 70o-90o at 30 oC and 120 °C (shown in the inset of Figure 1c and Figure S2). As the temperature decreased from 120 oC to 30 oC, the (311) reflection peak split into (113) and (311) peaks, meanwhile the (302) reflection split into (302) and (320) peaks. This lattice symmetry variation is attributed to the paraelectric-ferroelectric ferroelectric phase transition in BaTiO3.
[13] The temperature-dependent Raman spectra of 10 nm BaTiO3 NPs are presented in Figure 1d. The main spectral features observed at 20 oC include a sharp peak at ~306 cm-1 [B1, E(TO+LO)], a broad peak centered at ~520 cm-1 [A1, E(TO)] and an asymmetric broad peak at ~720 cm-1 [A1, E(LO)], indicating the noncentrosymmetric ferroelectric characteristic of the BaTiO3 NPs.[14] These characteristic peaks become broaden with weaker intensities as temperature increases. The change of the linewidth at ~306 cm-1 with increasing temperature is plotted in the inset of Figure 1d. It gradually increases from 20 oC and finally levels off around 80 oC. This result suggests a large structural distortion and diffusion of the ferroelectric phase transition within a temperature range from 20 oC to 120 oC. These findings indicate that the ferroelectric phase of assynthesized BaTiO3 is stable at room temperature but different from the bulk BaTiO3 which has a sharp transition temperature for the paraelectric-to-ferroelectric first-order phase transition.
To realize the applications for water splitting, it is necessary to make BaTiO3 NPs dispersible in an aqueous media. Here, the surface-bound capping ligands of BaTiO3 were removed by a ligand-exchange process which was achieved by introducing excess diethylamine (DEA) into the colloid.[15] The native capping ligands can be effectively removed due to the strong
coordination effect of DEA. DEA, as a small amine molecule, can be conveniently removed from the BaTiO3 surface. Thus, BaTiO3 with a clean surface was obtained. The photograph in Figure S3a shows that BaTiO3 NPs with capping ligands and BaTiO3 NPs with clean surfaces are well-dispersed in hexane and water, respectively. TEM images of BaTiO3 NPs with clean surface demonstrates a high level of monodispersibility in water (Figure S3b). As shown in Figure S4, vibrational bands of the ligand can be clearly detected from OA-capped BaTiO3 NPs, for example, at 1424 (-C=O) and 868 (-CH-). These bands completely disappeared after the surface treatment processes, confirming that the ligand molecules were completely removed from the BaTiO3 NPs.
Figure 1. (a) TEM image of BaTiO3 nanocubes. Scale bar, 50 nm. (b) HRTEM image of BaTiO3 nanocubes. Scale bar, 2 nm. (c) XRD pattern of BaTiO3 nanocubes. The inset shows the XRD patterns of BaTiO3 nanocubes at 30 oC and 120 oC. (d) The Raman spectra at different temperatures of BaTiO3 nanocubes in which the inset is the full width at half-maximum (FWHM) of the ~306 cm-1 Raman peak of BaTiO3 nanocubes at different temperatures.
For convenience of nanoscale ferroelectric properties characterization, the monodisperse BaTiO3 nanocubes were orderly dispersed on a smooth substrate by the spin coating method.[16] The SEM image as shown in Figure S5 clearly indicates that nanocubes are oriented along the same direction with a 10 nm wide periodical stripe patterns probed by PFM.]17] The surface roughness of the assembled BaTiO3 film is also presented. The AFM image also demonstrates that the film is flat and its surface roughness is as small as approximately 30 nm (Figure S6). For comparison, the 200 nm BaTiO3 nanocubes and BaTiO3 nanowires were simultaneously prepared (Figure S7). Voltages of ±20V were applied to the samples and the oscillation signals of the cantilever were read out as phase and amplitude signals. Local polarization-electric field loops (P-E) of the 10 nm BaTiO3 nanocubes present a clear hysteresis and 180˚ phase switching (Figure 2a) which indicates a strong ferroelectric response. Moreover, the butterfly-shaped amplitude curve verifies excellent local piezoelectric response. Ferroelectric domains can be written and read-out on BaTiO3 NPs films, as shown in the out-of-plane PFM image, which is ascribed to the smoothness of the film because of by the assembly of monodisperse BaTiO3 nanocubes.
]18] On BaTiO3 NPs films, a 10 V voltage switched a selected square domain to an upward polarization direction from its as-grown state. Figure 2b and 2c show the out-of-plane PFM phase and amplitude images of ferroelectric domains written on the BaTiO3 NPs surface. The 180o phase contrast also reveals that the polarization directions are antiparallel with each other in the two domains, suggesting stable ferroelectric switching. The polarization bound charges on the crystal surface will form a depolarization field that requires screening from the free space charges.
In order to achieve a charge balance state on the polar surfaces of ferroelectric, the free charges (space charges) in the ambient environment will compensate the polarization bound charges to screen the polarization field. For ferroelectrics, external factors such as stress or temperature changes can lead to the change of polarization states and thus the density of the surface polarization bound charges on the sample surface. Therefore, on the sample surface, a temporary charge imbalance state between the polarization bound charges and the screening charge is created. In order to achieve a chargeneutral state, either the release or attraction of space charges will occur on the surface and will depend on either a decrease or increase of the polarization value. An oxidation-reduction reaction can be realized if this charge release and accumulation process can proceed alternatingly. Based on this logic, in our
experiment, we alternated the polarization state of our NPs by ultrasonication.
The piezoelectric coefficient of BaTiO3 NPs is the key parameter to evaluate the coupling between the mechanical to electrical properties, however, it is not easy to directly obtain.[19] Here, the approximate effective piezoelectric coefficient of 10 nm BaTiO3 NPs, 200 nm BaTiO3 NPs and BaTiO3 nanowires were determined by PFM measurement. To minimize the contribution of spurious electrostatic effects, the spring constant of the cantilever was calibrated. The acquired calibrated piezoresponse amplitude signals as a function of bias were obtained on these samples where the slope of the acquired response reveals an effective longitudinal piezoelectric coefficient (deff).
[19a] From the fitting results shown in Figure 2d, the effective longitudinal piezoelectric coefficients of 10 nm BaTiO3 NPs, 200 nm BaTiO3 NPs and BaTiO3 nanowires are about 0.45 pm/V, 0.06 pm/V and 0.09 pm/V respectively. This result indicates that the electromechanical responses is enhanced in 10 nm BaTiO3 NPs when compared to 200 nm BaTiO3 NPs and BaTiO3 nanowires.
In order to theoretically evaluate the piezo-catalytic efficiency for water splitting, the distribution of the piezoelectric potential in the BaTiO3 NPs was numerically simulated based on the measured the piezoelectric coefficients.[20] In the simulation, the pressure (108 Pa) induced by ultrasonic cavitation acts on the BaTiO3 with different morphologies and sizes close to realistic dimensions as shown by TEM. The highest potential can be found in 10 nm BaTiO3 compared to 200 nm BaTiO3 NPs and BaTiO3 nanowires due to their excellent piezoelectric coefficient. The piezoelectric potential values for the 200 nm BaTiO3 NPs and BaTiO3 nanowires are 0.5 V and 1.2 V (Figure S9), respectively. The piezoelectric potential of 10 nm BaTiO3 can reach the highest potential value of 2.6 V, despite the small volume due to its size, exceeding the required Gibbs free energy change of the water-splitting reaction (1.23 V).[21] Thus the 10 nm BaTiO3 NPs would produce improved catalysis and efficiency of water splitting under a given stimulus.
To better understand the underlying mechanism of the high dielectric and piezoelectric properties, spherical aberrationcorrected scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) was employed to investigate the microstructure of assynthesized BaTiO3 NPs.
[22] Atomic-resolution high angle annular dark field (HAADF) STEM images of 10 nm BaTiO3 were recorded along the crystallographic [001] direction. Because the corner A-site atoms (Ba) are much heavier than the center B-site atoms (Ti), the A-site atomic columns are brighter than the B-site atomic columns in the HAADF STEM image. The positions of the corner A-site (Ba) and the center B-site (Ti) atomic columns of the perovskite ABO3 lattice structure can be clearly classified (Figure 4a), allowing for precise extraction of the B-site atomic displacements. In the unit-cell column of the atomic-resolution TEM image schematically shown in Figure S10, the distortion and tilting of the Ba2+ cation is negligible. The relative displacements of the center Ti4+ cation is presented as vectors pointing from the center of a B-site cation to the corner of its four nearest neighboring A-site cations. As mentioned previously, the magnitudes and directions of the polar vectors could represent the symmetries of three phases (T, O and R) of BaTiO3 (Figure 4b, c, d). [23] The coexistence of T, O, and R nanoregions are clearly observed in Figure 3a.
According to the polarization mappings the enhancement of piezoelectric properties might be due to the coexistence of these three ferroelectric phases (T+O+R). Such enhancement has been observed in other high-performance piezoelectric ceramic systems, for example Sm-doped Pb(Mg1/3Nb2/3)O3-PbTiO3 and Ba(Ti0.8Zr0.2)O3-(Ba0.7Ca0.3)TiO3.
[5b,23,24] The difference is that assynthesized BaTiO3 NPs without any doping possess a surface effect, which produced strong size-related effects and changed the local structure of the BaTiO3. As the particle size decreases to only several nanometers, the surface-to-volume ratio rapidly increases, and surface structure relaxation becomes significant due to size-dependent boundary effect. The atomic shifts could be induced by surface relaxation which acts to reduce the symmetry of the local structure of the BaTiO3. The local structure deviations lead to the coexistence of T, O, and R nanoregions in as-synthesized BaTiO3. In principle, the morphotropic phase boundary can lead to instability of the polarization state and the polarization direction can be easily rotated by external stress; thus, this resultant structural flexibility leads to high piezoelectric performance.
Based on polarization distribution, Landau free energy modeling is employed to determine the energy barriers of polarization rotation. Following the approach by Rossetti et al. and Haun et al., the Landau free energy of the BaTiO3 system can be expanded as a function of order parameter polarization
with respect to 6th order polynomial, including anisotropic and isotropic terms.[25]
Where α, βi, γj are the expansion coefficients for the polynomial which depends on composition and temperature and can determine the stability of different ferroelectric phases: T (001), O (110), R (111). p=np and n= (n1, n2, n3) (directional unit vector) represent the spontaneous polarization. Here p1=p2 is prescribed so that the (110) projection of the free energy profile can be expressed. In conventional first order polymorphic phase transition, no thermodynamic restriction to the anisotropy is produced, leading to anisotropy and a high energy difference between rhombohedral (R) phase and tetragonal (T) phase (as shown in Figure S11). However, for the multiphase convergence region, the free energy is independent of polarization direction (Figure 3f) and the energy profile shows an almost flat free energy landscape (Figure 3e). The energy barrier for polarization rotation from (001) T state to (111) R state is minuscule, facilitating a much easier polarization rotation.[26] The findings suggest a simultaneous coexistence of three ferroelectric phases (T+O+R) which could decrease the energy barrier and the polarization anisotropy, leading to a high piezoelectric and dielectric properties.

sections.heading: RESEARCH ARTICLE
sections.text:
To shed light on the advantage of the nano-ferroelectricity, the piezocatalysis hydrogen and oxygen evolution activities of assynthesized BaTiO3 were evaluated in pure aqueous solution under ultrasonic wave vibrations. Figure 4a shows that hydrogen and oxygen are steadily produced at rates of around 655 and 316 µmolg-1h-1 under 60 kHz ultrasonic vibration, respectively. As expected, the mole ratio of hydrogen and oxygen evolution is nearly 2:1. Furthermore, there are negligible drops in the rates of hydrogen and oxygen production during four consecutive cycles in a total time of ∼15 h, suggesting excellent stability of piezocatalysis for 10 nm BaTiO3. The effect of frequency on piezocatalytic hydrogen and oxygen production was also investigated. As shown in Figure 4b and Figure S12, the gas evolution rises with an increase in ultrasonic frequency. As is well known, water generates cavitation bubbles under ultrasonic oscillation, and the cavitation bubbles subsequently explode and high local pressure is produced (>100 MPa).[27] The discontinuous compressive stress acts on the BaTiO3 NPs, leading to a change in piezoelectric polarization of BaTiO3 due to the crystal-lattice dilating and constricting (Figure S13). A periodic absorption and release process of free charge in aqueous solution occurs on the surface of ferroelectric nanoparticles. The released charges can directly react with the water molecules and produce hydrogen and oxygen.[20a] Thus, high-frequency vibration could enhance the piezoelectric effect and increase gas production.
The overall water splitting activity was further investigated under different concentrations of BaTiO3. In Figure 4c and Figure S14, the yield of hydrogen and oxygen is very low at lower concentrations (<10 wt%) and rapidly increases as the concentration of BaTiO3 increases. When the concentration of the BaTiO3 NPs is higher than 10 wt%, the evolution rate of hydrogen and oxygen slows down. This may indicate that the catalysis effect is related to the distance between the adjacent nanoparticles. In the piezocatalysis process, the adjacent nanoparticles with a head-and-tail alignment could form an instantaneous electric field.[20b] With increasing concentration of 10 nm BaTiO3, the instantaneous electric field can be enhanced due to the shortening of distance between adjacent nanoparticles, leading to a higher concentration of hydrogen and oxygen evolution. However, at even higher concentration, the evolution rate of hydrogen and oxygen plateaus due to the agglomeration of the nanoparticles in the ultrasound process.
For comparison, the 200 nm BaTiO3 nanocubes and BaTiO3 nanowires were also measured for hydrogen and oxygen production (Figure 4d). The gas evolution rates of the 200 nm BaTiO3 are close to zero. Moreover, the efficiency of BaTiO3 nanowires for overall water splitting is much lower than that of 10 nm BaTiO3 (Figure S15). This is because for BaTiO3 of a larger particle size, the piezoelectric potential does not exceed the free energy of water splitting (1.23 eV) or the large overpotential of water oxidation half-reaction. In the same way the 10 nm BaTiO3 displays significantly higher piezocatalytic activity when compared to the 200 nm BaTiO3 nanocubes and BaTiO3 nanowires in degradation of Rhodamine B (Rh B) under 40 kHz ultrasonic (Figure 4e). This leads to a ≈100% decomposition rate of Rh B in 30 min for 10 nm BaTiO3, while the 200 nm BaTiO3 nanocubes and BaTiO3 nanowires can decompose only ≈9% of Rh B and ≈13% of Rh B, respectively.
These results provide further evidence that the as-synthesized BaTiO3 NPs with 10 nm diameter have a higher degree of piezoelectricity than the BaTiO3 NPs of a larger size. Based on these observations, we present the schematic of the origin of the ultrahigh piezocatalysis activity of 10 nm BaTiO3 (as illustrated in Figure 4f). The ferroelectric polarization is enhanced by a periodic pressure along the polarization direction. The free electrons and protons within the catalysis’s surroundings are attracted to BaTiO3 surfaces that are perpendicular to the polarization direction which acts to induce a high surface potential. The piezoelectric potential is large enough to achieve the potential energy required for water splitting (1.23 eV). When the pressure is removed, the previously accumulated free charge on the BaTiO3 surfaces are released to split water.

sections.heading: Conclusion
sections.text:
In conclusion, we successfully demonstrated a new nanoferroelectric candidate, 10 nm BaTiO3 nanoparticles, which possess excellent catalytic activity for overall water splitting without sacrificial electron donors under ultrasonic vibration which is believed to originate from the NPs heightened piezoelectric activity. By imaging local ferroelectric distortions at atomic-resolution using STEM mapping, the origin of the high piezoelectricity is revealed to be associated with the coexistence of multiple phases (T+O+R) with low energy barriers and polarization anisotropy. The phase structural flexibility of the ferroelectric NPs with reduced polarization anisotropy is also presented in the context of Landau free energy modeling. In the piezocatalysis process (60 kHz ultrasonic), the high PE of 10 nm BaTiO3 was able to induce exceptionally highly overall water splitting activity, with H2 production rate as high as 655 µmolg
-1h1, which could be competitive with current photocatalysis methods.

referenceMentions.context: Among them, photocatalytic water splitting using oxide semiconductors under sunlight irradiation has been widely reported.([3]) However, the practical application of photocatalytic hydrogen production is currently limited due to low quantum efficiency, design complexity, and lack of response in absence of sunlight.

metadata.abstractText: Piezocatalysis, converting mechanical vibration into chemical energy, has emerged as a promising candidate for watersplitting technology. However, the efficiency of the hydrogen production is quite limited. We herein report well-defined 10 nm BaTiO3 nanoparticles (NPs) characterized by a large electromechanical coefficient which induces a high piezoelectric effect. Atomic-resolution high angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) and scanning probe microscopy (SPM) suggests that piezoelectric BaTiO3 NPs display a coexistence of multiple phases with low energy barriers and polarization anisotropy which results in a high electromechanical coefficient. Landau free energy modeling also confirms that the greatly reduced polarization anisotropy facilitates polarization rotation. Employing the high piezoelectric properties of BaTiO3 NPs, we demonstrate an overall water-splitting process with the highest hydrogen production efficiency hitherto reported, with a H2 production rate of 655 μmolg h, which could rival excellent photocatalysis system. This study highlights the potential of piezoelectric catalysis for overall water splitting.
